@jakirkham - I've been meaning to contact the jupyter mailing list along those lines (with links to each of the feedstocks). Are you interested in sending that message maybe?

While I definitely intended to add the bulk of Jupyter packages, you were too fast for me. :runner: :smile:

That's ok though. I think I have tried to explicitly state my interest on some of them. Will add myself and/or more Jupyter packages soon.

I think a similar message to the mailing list (which has threads) would be a good thing to do, if you are happy to do it? We can also be more concrete now, as we have all of the feedstocks to point to...
Absolutely, I'll try to write a draft and share it with you, @ocefpaf, and whoever else you guys think is relevant. Would be good to make this a little bit more formal.
Probably just me on this particular repo, but a ping to the list would be great. The chat doesn't get seen by many who aren't paying attention at the time.
I don't like all those spaces, but that is unimportant.
It doesn't use `setuptools` unless we are installing in `develop` mode or we are building some sort of `bdist` for shipping.

My personal habit for conda packages is to use `pip install --no-deps .`, because it ensures two things:
- packages that _do_ import setuptools unconditionally don't lay an egg
- packages that _don't_ import setuptools for install (specifically to avoid the egg), can still have their setuptools extras_require, etc. (IPython does this)

I have a hard time thinking of any cases where `setup.py install` is preferable to `pip install .`.

3. It is the future...?

Personal confession, I _never_ `pip install .`. That said, it might be the healthy thing to be doing on conda-forge.

We have been adding other options like `--single-version-externally-managed --record record.txt` when using packages with `setuptools`, which has worked nicely so far. Though you do make a good point as `pip install --no-deps .` would avoid us having to check this at all. However, leaving `--no-deps` off could be ok as this will raise red flags if we missed adding a dependency as `conda` terminates any build if it tries to download requirements with `pip`.

comments.body:
So, I'm not sure that I like that as the default. Here is my reasoning (partially motivated by @ocefpaf).

When one makes a PyPI release, it is basically impossible to overwrite the file submitted with the release. However, with GitHub tags this is trivial. Now it's true that people shouldn't do that, but the fact that it is possible and one might be tempted to is enough of a reason for me to steer clear.

The checksum sort of prevents against this, but then if it does become inaccurate we aren't sure if the release has been modified in some way, if we are having connectivity issues, or worse someone is tampering with what we are receiving. If we determine it has been modified (probably by repeated attempts), it is hard for us to tell as the old tag doesn't exist any more and we might not know the commit (assuming it even still exists).

TL;DR PyPI gives us some nice guarantees that GitHub doesn't. These guarantees protect us and our users. We should really embrace them.
